The number of lanes is reduced to one

The highway is changing into a parking lot
The speed limit is automatically doubled
Only trucks may continue on the road

Signal left for the entire time you are in the roundabout
Never signal in a roundabout
Signal hazard lights while driving through

Owning the newest and most powerful vehicle
Driving as fast as traffic will allow
Relying on other drivers to avoid collisions
explanation: The handbook emphasizes that safe driving is not just about skills, but also about your attitude: being courteous, patient and focused on safety for everyone on the road.

Half a second, to react quickly
No more than one car length
Only enough space so another car cannot fit in
explanation: The handbook describes the two-second rule as a simple way to check you have enough space to react to sudden stops on dry, clear roads. More space is needed in bad conditions.

question: To spot hazards early, how should you scan the road while driving in city traffic?
choices: Keep your eyes moving, checking far ahead, around and in your mirrors regularly
Stare only at the vehicle directly in front of you
Look straight down at the road just beyond your hood
Check your mirrors once at the start of the trip
explanation: Safe drivers constantly scan: they look well ahead, side-to-side, and check mirrors often. This helps them see hazards early and react in time.

question: At night, how should you adjust your speed, even if the posted speed limit is higher?
choices: Drive slowly enough that you can stop within the distance lit by your headlights
Always drive at the posted limit because it is safe at all times
Speed up so you spend less time in the dark
Use high beams and drive as fast as possible
explanation: At night you must not overdrive your headlights. You should drive at a speed that lets you stop within the distance you can see clearly ahead.

question: At a four-way stop where all vehicles arrive around the same time, which driver should normally go first?
choices: The driver who comes to a complete stop first and proceeds when it is safe
The driver with the largest vehicle
The driver who flashes headlights first
The driver who is turning left across traffic
explanation: At four-way stops, the vehicle that comes to a full stop first usually goes first, but all drivers must make sure the way is clear and safe before moving.

question: Before changing lanes on a multi-lane road, what is the correct sequence?
choices: Check mirrors, signal, shoulder check, then change lanes when safe
Signal after you move, then check mirrors
Move first, then check mirrors and signal
Honk and move into the next lane immediately
explanation: The handbook teaches a clear routine: mirror check, signal, shoulder check to cover blind spots, and then change lanes only when it is safe.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Lane changes

question: Why is a shoulder check important even if you have properly adjusted mirrors?
choices: There are areas beside your vehicle that mirrors cannot show (blind spots)
It is only a habit and not necessary
It lets other drivers know you are turning
It replaces the need to signal
explanation: Even correctly adjusted mirrors cannot show everything. A quick shoulder check helps you see vehicles, cyclists or pedestrians in your blind spots.

question: When entering an expressway from an on-ramp, what should you do on the acceleration lane?
choices: Signal, match the speed of traffic, and merge when there is a safe gap
Stop at the end of the ramp and wait for someone to let you in
Drive slowly on the shoulder until you find a large gap
Reverse if you miss your exit
explanation: On expressway ramps you should accelerate to match traffic speed, signal and merge smoothly when there is a safe opening.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Expressway driving (entering)

question: When exiting an expressway, when should you start to slow down?
choices: After you have entered the deceleration lane or exit ramp
As soon as you see your exit sign, on the main lane
Only once you reach the next city street
Never; keep highway speed through the exit
explanation: You should maintain expressway speed until you are in the deceleration lane or ramp, then slow down safely to the posted exit speed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Expressway driving (leaving)

question: On a two-way road, you hear and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights and siren approaching from behind. What must you do?
choices: Move as far to the right as possible and stop until it has passed
Speed up to stay ahead of the emergency vehicle
Stop in the centre of the road
Turn left and block oncoming traffic
explanation: When an emergency vehicle is approaching with lights and siren, you must move to the right, clear the intersection if you are in it, and stop until it has passed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with emergency vehicles

question: On a multi-lane highway, you see a stopped emergency vehicle with flashing lights on the shoulder of your lane. What should you do if traffic allows?
choices: Move into another lane away from the emergency vehicle and slow down
Maintain your speed in the same lane
Honk and drive past as usual
Stop beside the emergency vehicle to watch
explanation: Ontario’s move-over rules require drivers to slow down and, where possible, move into another lane away from stopped emergency or tow vehicles with flashing lights.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Move-over law

question: When passing a cyclist on a two-lane road, how should you do it safely?
choices: Slow down and leave at least one metre of space between your vehicle and the cyclist when passing
Pass closely to prevent other vehicles from passing
Honk loudly and pass at full speed
Drive on the shoulder to pass without changing lanes
explanation: Drivers must give cyclists enough space when passing. Ontario law requires at least one metre where practical, and the handbook encourages extra space whenever possible.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with cyclists

question: You are parked beside a bike lane and want to open your driver’s door. What is the safest way to avoid hitting a cyclist?
choices: Check mirrors, shoulder check for cyclists, then open the door with your far hand
Open the door quickly without looking so it is open for less time
Rely on cyclists to stop if a door opens
Leave the door open while you look for traffic
explanation: To prevent “dooring” collisions, the handbook recommends checking mirrors and blind spots and using your far hand to open the door, forcing you to turn and look.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with cyclists (door zone)

question: Why must you take extra care when judging the speed and distance of oncoming motorcycles?
choices: They are smaller and can appear farther away and slower than they really are
They always travel below the speed limit
They are required to stop at every intersection
They do not use headlights in the daytime
explanation: Because motorcycles are small, drivers often misjudge how far away and how fast they are moving. This is important when turning left or crossing in front of a motorcycle.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with motorcycles

question: When driving near large trucks, why should you avoid travelling for long periods right beside them?
choices: Trucks have large blind spots and need extra room to maneuver
Trucks are always speeding
Trucks must drive in the centre of the road
You have the right-of-way, so position does not matter
explanation: Large vehicles have big blind spots along their sides and need more space to turn and change lanes. Avoid staying beside them and pass safely when you can.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with large vehicles

question: A large truck signals a right turn and moves slightly to the left before turning. What should you do?
choices: Do not move into the space on the right; the truck needs room to turn
Drive up on the right side to pass during the turn
Honk and force the truck to stay in its lane
Move into the bike lane beside the truck
explanation: Large vehicles often swing wide to make right turns. Never pull up beside them on the turning side; stay back until the turn is completed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Large vehicles making wide turns

question: On a snowy road with reduced traction, how should you adjust your following distance?
choices: Increase it well beyond the normal two-second rule
Keep the same following distance as on dry roads
Reduce it so other drivers cannot move in
Follow as closely as possible to use the other driver’s tire tracks
explanation: In snow or ice, you need much more distance to stop. The handbook recommends increasing following distance significantly in poor conditions.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Winter driving and following distance

question: On a near-freezing day, why should you be especially cautious on bridges and overpasses?
choices: They can freeze and become icy before the rest of the road
They are always perfectly dry
They are heated and never freeze
They have extra traction compared to other roads
explanation: Bridges and overpasses lose heat more quickly and can develop black ice even when nearby roads look clear.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Winter driving (black ice)

question: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane on a very wet road, what is the safest action?
choices: Ease off the accelerator and steer straight until you regain traction
Brake hard and steer sharply
Shift to Neutral and turn off the ignition
Accelerate to get through the water faster
explanation: Hydroplaning happens when tires lose contact with the road on water. Gently easing off the accelerator and keeping the wheels straight helps regain traction.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driving in rain and hydroplaning

question: When must you use your headlights, even during the daytime?
choices: Whenever visibility is poor enough that you cannot clearly see people or vehicles 150 metres ahead
Only at night on country roads
Only in winter months
Only when using high beams
explanation: Ontario’s rules require you to use headlights when visibility is poor, such as in heavy rain, snow, or fog, so others can see you.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Headlights and visibility

question: When parking uphill on a street with a curb, how should you turn your front wheels?
choices: Turn the front wheels away from the curb and set the parking brake
Turn the wheels straight ahead
Turn the front wheels toward the curb
It does not matter which way the wheels point
explanation: When parking uphill with a curb, turning the wheels away from the curb helps keep the vehicle from rolling into traffic if it moves.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking on hills

3 demerit points
4 demerit points
6 demerit points
explanation: Failing to stop at a pedestrian crossover or similar protected crossing carries 4 demerit points in Ontario.

4 demerit points
6 demerit points
7 demerit points
explanation: Failing to remain at the scene of a collision is among the most serious offences and carries 7 demerit points in Ontario.

question: You see this sharp left curve warning sign with an advisory speed plate under it. How should you drive?

Maintain your current speed and brake hard in the middle of the curve
Accelerate into the curve to stay in your lane
Drive on the shoulder to avoid the curve
explanation: Sharp curve signs often come with an advisory speed. Slow to about that speed before the curve and steer smoothly to maintain control.

question: As you approach this sharp right curve sign on a two-lane road, what is the safest approach to passing?
choices: Do not pass other vehicles in or near the sharp curve
Pass other vehicles quickly in the middle of the curve
Pass if you cannot see oncoming traffic
Passing is allowed at any speed
explanation: Sharp curves limit your sight line. You should not pass other vehicles approaching or within a sharp curve because you may not see oncoming traffic in time.

Use cruise control to keep a steady speed
Brake sharply to test road grip
Speed up to get through the slippery area faster
explanation: A slippery-when-wet sign means the surface may be slick in rain. Slow down, avoid sudden movements and hard braking, and keep extra space from other vehicles.

You must drive exactly 80 km/h
You must drive at least 80 km/h at all times
The speed limit applies only to trucks

Turn off your engine to save fuel
Coast in Neutral to go down faster
Shift into a high gear and brake only at the bottom

In the middle of the intersection
Halfway into the crosswalk
Anywhere as long as you pause briefly
explanation: At a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the stop line, before the crosswalk, or before entering the intersection, whichever comes first.

A railway crossing is directly ahead
A four-way stop with no lights
The road ends in a cul-de-sac
explanation: The traffic-signal-ahead warning sign alerts you to a signalized intersection ahead so you can prepare to reduce speed or stop if the light changes.

Parking is free for everyone
Parking is for motorcycles only
You may park here only at night
explanation: The wheelchair symbol marks accessible parking. Only vehicles with a valid accessible parking permit may park in these spaces.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking and accessible spaces

Turn the wheels into the centre of the road
Leave the wheels straight and in Neutral
Turn the wheels left and do not use the parking brake
explanation: Facing downhill without a curb, turning the wheels toward the shoulder helps keep the vehicle from rolling into the roadway.

Hydrants are reserved parking for fire trucks only
Hydrants mark private driveways
Parking there is allowed at night only
explanation: Parking rules include minimum distances from fire hydrants so emergency crews can connect hoses without delay.

It makes crossing easier for pedestrians
It is only a suggestion with no safety concern
It is allowed if your hazard lights are on
explanation: Parking too close to crosswalks can hide pedestrians from view and make it harder for drivers to see them in time.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking restrictions near crosswalks

question: If your vehicle stalls on a railway crossing and a train is approaching, what should you do first?

Stay inside and try to restart until the last moment
Push the vehicle off the tracks alone
Stand directly in front of the train to signal it to stop
explanation: The handbook advises that if a train is coming and you cannot move the vehicle, you must get everyone out and move away at an angle to avoid flying debris.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Railway crossings (if your vehicle stalls)

question: If a front tire blows out while you are driving, what is the safest initial reaction?
choices: Hold the steering wheel firmly, ease off the accelerator and steer straight
Brake hard immediately and turn to the shoulder
Accelerate to keep the vehicle stable
Turn sharply away from the side of the blown tire
explanation: A tire blowout can cause sudden pulling. You should hold the wheel firmly, gently ease off the gas, and steer straight until you can slow and pull off safely.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Handling tire blowouts

question: On an icy road, your rear wheels begin to skid sideways. What should you do?
choices: Steer gently in the direction you want the front of the car to go and avoid braking hard
Brake as hard as possible and hold the pedal down
Steer in the opposite direction of the skid quickly
Turn the steering wheel fully to one side and accelerate
explanation: To correct a skid, steer in the direction you want to go and avoid sudden braking or acceleration, which can make the skid worse.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Skids and how to handle them

question: You start to feel very drowsy while driving. What is the safest decision?
choices: Find a safe place to stop and rest before continuing
Open the window and keep driving at the same speed
Turn up the radio and focus on staying awake
Drink coffee and continue driving for several more hours
explanation: Driver fatigue is dangerous. The only safe choice is to stop and rest. Tricks like loud music or open windows do not remove the risk.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driver fatigue

question: Another driver is following you too closely (tailgating). What is the safest way to respond?
choices: Gradually increase your following distance and, when safe, change lanes or let them pass
Brake suddenly to warn them
Speed up to get away from them
Ignore them and drive exactly the same way
explanation: To reduce risk from tailgaters, give yourself more space ahead and, if possible, let them pass safely instead of reacting aggressively.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Dealing with aggressive drivers

question: How often should you normally check your mirrors while driving on a straight road with light traffic?
choices: Every few seconds, and before slowing, turning or changing lanes
Only when you hear a horn
Once at the beginning and once at the end of the trip
Only when you plan to stop
explanation: Frequent mirror checks help you stay aware of traffic behind and beside you so you can react safely to changes.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Observing traffic around you

question: For a G1 or G2 driver, what is the legal blood alcohol requirement while driving?

A small amount of alcohol is allowed if you feel okay
You may drink as long as you stay under the fully licensed limit
There are no alcohol rules for G1/G2 drivers
explanation: Ontario has a zero-tolerance rule for alcohol for novice drivers (G1 and G2). They must have a blood alcohol concentration of 0.00 while driving.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Impaired driving and novice drivers

question: Which of the following is a requirement for a G1 driver when driving on public roads?
choices: A fully licensed driver with at least four years of experience must sit in the front passenger seat
Any friend with a licence can sit in the back seat
No other person needs to be in the vehicle
Only another G1 driver is required as a supervisor
explanation: G1 drivers must be accompanied in the front seat by a fully licensed driver with the required years of driving experience and a valid blood alcohol level.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — G1 licence conditions

question: Which statement about G1 drivers and high-speed roads is correct?
choices: G1 drivers are not allowed on certain high-speed expressways unless accompanied by a qualified driving instructor
G1 drivers may drive alone on all expressways at any time
G1 drivers are allowed only on toll roads
G1 drivers must drive only on unpaved roads
explanation: Some high-speed expressways are restricted for G1 drivers unless a qualified instructor is present. This helps new drivers gain experience in lower-risk environments first.

To limit fuel use for young drivers
To make public transit more popular
To prevent G2 drivers from driving during the day
explanation: The handbook explains that restrictions on young G2 drivers at night are designed to reduce crash risk when experience is still limited.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — G2 licence conditions

Leave quickly if your car can still move
Move your car home and report only if you feel like it
Stay in the vehicle and block traffic until a tow truck arrives
explanation: Drivers involved in collisions must stop, provide their information and follow the law about when and how to report the collision.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — After a collision

question: When should you use your turn signal?
choices: Whenever you plan to turn, change lanes, or move away from a parked position
Only when other traffic is heavy
Only when driving at night
Only when approaching a stop sign
explanation: Turn signals communicate your intentions to others. You should use them for turns, lane changes and pulling in or out of traffic.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Using turn signals

question: What is the safest way to back up a vehicle?
choices: Check all around, look out the rear window and back up slowly
Rely only on mirrors and back up quickly
Use only the rear-view camera and do not look anywhere else
Back up by looking forward and using your side mirrors only
explanation: When reversing, you must check all around, look mainly out the rear window and move slowly to avoid hazards.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Backing up safely

question: You are turning right at an intersection and the light is green. A pedestrian begins crossing the street you are turning into. What must you do?
choices: Yield to the pedestrian and wait until they have safely crossed
Honk and turn in front of the pedestrian
Turn quickly behind the pedestrian
Drive into the crosswalk to show you intend to turn
explanation: Drivers turning must yield to pedestrians lawfully in the crosswalk. You must wait until they clear your path before completing the turn.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Pedestrian right-of-way at intersections

question: At a crosswalk without traffic lights but with painted lines and signs, a pedestrian is waiting to cross. What is your responsibility?
choices: Be prepared to stop and allow the pedestrian to cross safely
Continue at the same speed because there is no traffic light
Stop only if the pedestrian steps directly in front of you
Accelerate to pass before the pedestrian begins crossing
explanation: Drivers must watch for pedestrians at signed and marked crossings and be ready to stop to let them cross safely.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Pedestrian crossings and driver duties

question: You have answered many practice questions in a row and feel your concentration dropping. What is the safest real-world driving habit to learn from this?

Force yourself to continue driving without a break
Increase your speed so the trip ends sooner
Use your phone to stay entertained while driving
explanation: Just like with studying, long periods of driving can cause fatigue and lost focus. Taking regular breaks helps you stay alert and safe.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driver fatigue and long trips

Half a car length per 10 km/h
One second behind the vehicle ahead
As close as possible without losing sight of the rear tires
explanation: The MTO recommends using the two-second rule in ideal conditions to give drivers enough time to react and stop safely.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Following Distance

question: At a four-way stop, two vehicles arrive at the same time. Who should proceed first?

The vehicle on the left has the right-of-way
The vehicle going straight always goes first
The largest vehicle goes first
explanation: When two vehicles arrive at a four-way stop simultaneously, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Intersections

question: Before changing lanes on a multi-lane road, what must a driver do to check blind spots properly?

Rely only on the rear-view mirror
Speed up to avoid vehicles beside you
Signal and drift toward the lane slowly until other drivers honk
explanation: Blind spots cannot be seen in mirrors. Shoulder-checks ensure no vehicles, cyclists, or motorcycles are hidden beside you.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Blind Spots

question: When must you dim your high-beam headlights at night?
choices: Whenever you are within 150 metres of an oncoming vehicle
Only when the other driver flashes their lights
Only on well-lit streets
Only when following a police vehicle
explanation: High beams must be dimmed within 150 metres of oncoming traffic to avoid impairing the vision of other drivers.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Headlights

question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights and siren approaches from behind, what must you do?
choices: Signal, pull as far right as possible, and stop
Speed up to avoid blocking them
Continue driving but move slightly to the left
Stop immediately in your lane, even on a highway
explanation: Drivers must pull far right and stop to allow emergency vehicles to pass safely and quickly.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency Vehicles

question: You are driving on a two-lane road with no median. A school bus ahead has stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm extended. What must you do?
choices: Slow down and pass carefully if no children are visible
Stop before reaching the bus and do not move until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm is folded away
Sound your horn and drive past at a reduced speed
Stop only if you are travelling in the same direction as the bus
explanation: On a road without a median, drivers in both directions must stop for a school bus with red lights flashing and the stop arm extended, and remain stopped until the signals are off and the arm is folded away.

sources.title: Official MTO School Bus Handbook — Stopping-for-school-buses law

notes: Covers basic full-stop requirement for school buses on undivided roads.

question: You are driving on a roadway divided by a median. A school bus on the opposite side stops with red lights flashing and stop arm extended. What must you do?
choices: Stop and remain stopped until the bus moves
Slow down and proceed with caution; you are not required to stop on the opposite side of a median
Honk to warn the bus driver and continue at normal speed
Change lanes to the far left and continue at the speed limit
explanation: On a divided roadway with a physical median, only vehicles travelling in the same direction as the bus are required to stop. Drivers on the opposite side should still slow and be prepared for children but are not legally required to stop.

sources.title: Official MTO School Bus Handbook — Stopping-for-school-buses law

notes: Highlights the median exception to the school-bus stopping law.

question: How close are you allowed to park to a fire hydrant in Ontario?
choices: Within one metre, as long as the hydrant is still visible
At least two metres away from the hydrant
At least three metres away from the hydrant
Any distance is allowed if you stay in the vehicle
explanation: You must not park within three metres of a fire hydrant. This allows firefighters room to connect hoses quickly in an emergency.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking along roadways

notes: Parking restriction distance for fire hydrants.

question: On a road without traffic lights, how close are you allowed to park to an intersection or crosswalk?
choices: You may park right at the corner if you signal
At least three metres away from the intersection
At least nine metres away from the intersection
At least 15 metres away from the intersection
explanation: You must not park within nine metres of an intersection on roads without traffic lights. This helps keep sightlines clear for drivers and pedestrians.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking along roadways

notes: Parking distance rule near intersections without signals.

question: When you are required to stop at a railway crossing, how far from the nearest rail should you stop?
choices: Right on the tracks to see better in both directions
No closer than one metre from the nearest rail
At least five metres from the nearest rail
At least 20 metres from the nearest rail
explanation: Drivers must stop at least five metres from the nearest rail when required to stop at a railway crossing, leaving room for trains that are wider than the tracks.

sources.title: Ontario Road Safety Resource — Railway crossing safety

notes: Basic stopping distance rule at railway crossings.

question: On a 400-series highway you see diamond symbols and HOV (carpool) lane signs. When are you allowed to use this lane?
choices: Only when your vehicle has at least two people (or is an eligible vehicle such as a bus, motorcycle, or green-plate vehicle)
Whenever traffic in the regular lanes is slow and you want to pass
Only if you are driving at or above the speed limit
Any time after 7 p.m. and on weekends, regardless of passengers
explanation: High-occupancy vehicle (HOV) lanes are reserved for vehicles with at least two people on board, and some specially permitted vehicles such as buses, motorcycles, and eligible green-plate vehicles. They are not passing lanes for single-occupant cars, even when traffic is slow.

Ontario HOV lane rules and penalties (summary)

question: A driver is convicted of not wearing a seatbelt and allowing a child to ride unbelted. How many demerit points can seatbelt-related offences add to the driver’s record?
choices: 2 demerit points
3 demerit points
4 demerit points
6 demerit points
explanation: Seatbelt-related offences (including failing to ensure that passengers under 16 are properly secured) carry 2 demerit points each for the driver.

sources.title: Ontario — Demerit points table (seatbelt offences)

question: You force your way into traffic at this YIELD sign and are convicted of failing to yield the right-of-way. How many demerit points are added?
choices: 2 demerit points
3 demerit points
4 demerit points
6 demerit points
explanation: Failing to yield the right-of-way is a 3-point offence in Ontario.

sources.title: Ontario — Demerit points table (failing to yield the right-of-way)

question: This sign appears before a series of bends in the road. How should you drive?
choices: Reduce speed and be prepared for several curves in a row
Keep your current speed and brake only in the middle of each curve
Drive on the centre line to straighten the road
Stop before each curve and look both ways
explanation: A winding road warning sign tells you there are several curves ahead. You should slow down and drive smoothly through each curve, staying in your lane.

notes: New winding-road question focused on driving technique.

question: When you approach this YIELD sign and traffic is present on the main road, what must you do?
choices: Slow down and stop if necessary to let cross traffic go first
Drive through at normal speed
Stop even if the way is clear
Force your way into traffic because you have priority
explanation: A yield sign means you must give the right-of-way to traffic on the main road. Slow down, be prepared to stop, and proceed only when there is a safe gap.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driving through intersections (Yield signs)

notes: Second yield-sign question, emphasizing that stopping is required only if needed.

question: You see this DO NOT ENTER sign at the start of a lane. What does it tell you?
choices: You must not enter; the lane is for traffic coming toward you
You may enter only to turn left
The lane is reserved for buses only
You may enter if you turn on your hazard lights
explanation: A DO NOT ENTER sign means the lane or roadway is for oncoming traffic. You must not drive into it from your direction.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Regulatory signs (Do not enter)

notes: Different from the no-entry question; focuses on wrong-way one-way situations.

question: When this bicycle lane sign and markings appear on the right and you need to turn right at the next intersection, what should you do?
choices: Check for cyclists, signal right, then carefully enter the bike lane near the intersection to turn
Turn right without signaling because cyclists must yield
Drive in the bike lane for a long distance before turning
Never cross the bike lane, even to turn
explanation: Where there is a bike lane at the curb, you must check for cyclists, signal, and carefully move across it near the intersection to complete a right turn when safe.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with cyclists

notes: Second bike-lane question, focusing on turning right across the lane.

question: You see this pedestrian crossing sign and a person waiting at the edge of the crosswalk. What should you do?
choices: Slow down and be prepared to stop to let the pedestrian cross safely
Speed up to pass before the pedestrian starts crossing
Honk to tell the pedestrian to wait
Ignore the pedestrian because there are no traffic lights
explanation: At a pedestrian crossing, you must be ready to stop and allow waiting pedestrians to cross safely before you proceed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Pedestrian safety and crossings

notes: Second pedestrian-crossing question, now focusing on a waiting pedestrian.

question: At this railway crossing sign with no gates or lights, and no train in sight, what is the safest action?
choices: Slow down, look both ways, listen, and cross only when you are sure no train is coming
Drive through at full speed if the road looks clear
Stop on the tracks to look for trains
Use your horn instead of slowing down
explanation: At uncontrolled railway crossings, you must approach slowly, look and listen carefully in both directions, and cross only when it is clearly safe.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Railway crossings (Uncontrolled crossings)

notes: Second railway-crossing question, focusing on crossings with no gates or lights.

question: At night, you see this winding road sign and do not know the road. What is the best driving strategy?
choices: Reduce your speed, use low beams when approaching other traffic, and drive cautiously through each curve
Use high beams continuously and drive at the speed limit
Drive in the centre of the road to straighten the curves
Speed up to finish the winding section quickly
explanation: On an unfamiliar winding road at night, you should slow down, adjust headlights appropriately, and take each curve carefully to maintain control.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Night driving and curves

notes: Second winding-road question, focused on night driving strategy.

question: This triangular orange reflective sign is used on:
choices: Vehicles that travel slowly, such as farm machinery
Snowplows only
School buses only
Emergency vehicles
explanation: A slow-moving vehicle sign warns that the vehicle usually travels under 40 km/h.

question: You are driving on a multi-lane highway and see a police car stopped on the shoulder ahead with its red and blue lights flashing. What must you do?
choices: Slow down and move to a lane farther away if it is safe, or slow down and pass cautiously if you cannot change lanes
Maintain your speed but turn on your four-way flashers
Speed up to pass the emergency vehicle quickly so you are not in the danger area
Move into the lane next to the emergency vehicle to give it a clear shoulder
explanation: Ontario’s move-over rules require drivers to slow down and, if possible, move into another lane away from a stopped emergency vehicle with flashing lights. If you cannot safely change lanes, you must still reduce speed and pass with great caution.

notes: Covers the basic 'move over' requirement for emergency vehicles.

question: On a bridge you see lane-use control signals above each lane. The lane over you suddenly shows a red “X”. What should you do?
choices: Change to a lane with a green arrow as soon as you can do so safely
Ignore it if traffic in your lane is still moving
Stop in your lane and wait for the signal to turn green
Sound your horn and continue in your lane
explanation: A red “X” over a lane means that lane is closed to traffic and you must not drive in it. You should safely move into a lane that is marked with a downward green arrow.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook – Signs: Lane-use control signals
Lane-use control signals meanings (green arrow / red X)

notes: Explains red X vs green arrow lane-use signals.

question: You are approaching a rural side road intersection with no traffic lights or signs. What is the safest way to proceed?
choices: Slow down, be ready to stop, and yield to traffic already in the intersection or approaching from your right
Maintain your speed because there are no stop or yield signs
Use your horn and drive through quickly so you are not in the intersection for long
Stop only if you see headlights from another vehicle
explanation: At an uncontrolled intersection you must approach cautiously, be prepared to stop, and yield to traffic already in the intersection. If two vehicles arrive at about the same time, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook – Driving through intersections

question: You are waiting at a green light when a line of vehicles in a clearly marked funeral procession is still moving through the intersection. What should you do?
choices: Stay stopped and allow the entire procession to clear the intersection before you proceed
Drive into the gap between two vehicles in the procession so you don’t wait too long
Sound your horn to remind them that your light is green
Turn right on red to get around the procession
explanation: Funeral processions are given the right-of-way so they can remain together. Other drivers should be patient and allow the full procession to clear the intersection instead of cutting through or interrupting it.

sources.title: Sharing the road and special vehicles – funeral processions
Driving etiquette around funeral processions (right-of-way and courtesy)

notes: Courtesy and right-of-way around funeral processions.

question: Before changing lanes on a multi-lane road, what is the final check you must always perform?
choices: Check your blind spot by turning your head quickly
Only rely on your mirrors
Honk to alert other drivers
Speed up quickly to merge faster
explanation: Mirrors do not show your blind spot. A shoulder check ensures no vehicle or cyclist is beside you.

question: When an emergency vehicle approaches with lights and siren activated, you must:
choices: Move to the nearest curb and stop
Speed up to stay ahead
Continue driving at the limit
Stop immediately in your lane
explanation: Drivers must pull to the right and stop until the emergency vehicle passes.

question: Speeding excessively through a school zone may result in:
choices: Higher fines and demerit points
No penalty if it’s after school hours
A written warning only
Only a small fine with no points
explanation: School zones carry increased penalties due to vulnerable pedestrians.

question: What headlights should you use when driving in heavy fog?
choices: Low-beam headlights
High-beam headlights
Parking lights only
No lights at all
explanation: High beams reflect back in fog and reduce visibility. Low beams are safest.

question: When approaching a roundabout, you must:
choices: Yield to traffic already in the roundabout
Enter quickly to grab a gap
Stop completely before entering
Signal left as you enter
explanation: Vehicles inside the roundabout have the right-of-way. Enter when safe.

question: Which situation requires a longer stopping distance?
choices: Wet or icy pavement
Warm dry pavement
Light traffic
Daytime driving only
explanation: Reduced traction on wet or icy surfaces increases braking distance.

question: Hydroplaning occurs when:
choices: Your tires ride on top of water and lose road contact
You brake suddenly on dry pavement
Your car overheats in traffic
Your wipers stop working
explanation: Hydroplaning causes a loss of steering and braking control.

question: When merging onto a freeway, you should:
choices: Match the speed of traffic in the right lane
Stop at the end of the ramp
Enter at any speed
Drive on the shoulder
explanation: Accelerating to match traffic allows for a smooth merge.

question: If a front tire blows out while driving, what should you do first?
choices: Grip the wheel firmly and steer straight
Brake hard immediately
Turn quickly onto the shoulder
Accelerate sharply
explanation: A blowout can pull the vehicle to one side. Hold the wheel firmly and slow down gradually.

question: You see a sign marking a bus loading zone. What does this mean?
choices: Only buses may stop here
Anyone may park briefly
You may load passengers for 5 minutes
You may stop if your hazard lights are on
explanation: Bus zones are restricted to transit vehicles only.

question: Parking in a designated accessible parking spot without a permit may result in:
choices: Significant fines and towing
A small warning only
No penalty if you stay in the car
Only demerit points
explanation: Ontario enforces strict fines to protect accessibility.

question: A centre lane marked with left-turn arrows in both directions is used for:
choices: Left turns from either direction
Passing slower traffic
Parking temporarily
U-turns only
explanation: This shared lane is meant only for preparing and completing left turns.

question: When must you stop at a railway crossing, even if no train is visible?
choices: When flashing lights or gates are activated
Only at night
Only if a train whistle is heard
Never required unless a train is present
explanation: Active warnings always require a full stop.

question: When passing a cyclist, drivers must leave at least:
choices: 1 metre of space
20 centimetres
No required distance
As close as possible to avoid swerving
explanation: Ontario law requires a minimum 1-metre passing distance.

question: If you miss your exit on a freeway, you must:
choices: Continue to the next exit
Reverse carefully on the shoulder
Stop and wait for a gap
Make a U-turn in the median
explanation: Stopping or reversing on a freeway is extremely dangerous and illegal.

question: At an open (uncontrolled) intersection, who must yield?
choices: The driver who arrives later
The driver on the right
The driver on the left
No one must yield
explanation: If two vehicles arrive at roughly the same time, the one on the left yields to the right.

question: Impaired driving penalties for G1 drivers include:
choices: Immediate roadside suspension and escalating sanctions
No suspension unless over the criminal limit
Only a small fine
Demerit points only
explanation: G1 drivers must maintain a zero-blood-alcohol level and face strict penalties.

question: If a traffic signal is completely dark due to a power outage, treat the intersection as:
choices: A four-way stop
A normal green light
A pedestrian-only crossing
A yield sign for all directions
explanation: When signals fail, every driver must stop and proceed in turn.

question: The minimum recommended following distance under ideal conditions is:
choices: At least 2 seconds
Half a second
1 second
4 seconds at all times
explanation: A 2-second gap allows safe stopping time. Increase in poor conditions.

question: Why do bridges freeze before the rest of the road?
choices: They are exposed to cold air above and below
They use softer pavement
They hold more traffic
They receive more sunlight
explanation: Cold air flows around bridges, lowering their temperature faster.

question: In Ontario, when is a left turn on a red light permitted?
choices: Only from a one-way street onto another one-way street
Any time traffic is clear
Never permitted
Only when turning into a private driveway
explanation: A left turn on red is only allowed when moving from one one-way street to another.

question: In the absence of signs, what is the usual maximum speed limit on municipal roads in cities, towns, and villages in Ontario?
choices: 50 km/h
40 km/h
60 km/h
70 km/h
explanation: Unless posted otherwise, the default speed limit on many built-up municipal roads is 50 km/h. Drivers must still adjust speed for conditions.

question: You are facing a steady amber (yellow) traffic light and are far enough back to stop safely. What should you do?
choices: Stop before the intersection
Speed up to clear the intersection before red
Continue at the same speed
Drive into the intersection and wait for green
explanation: A steady amber light warns that the signal is about to turn red. If you can stop safely, you must stop before entering the intersection.

question: When may you turn right at a red traffic light in Ontario?
choices: After stopping and making sure the way is clear, unless a sign says no right turn on red
Any time, without stopping, if no one is coming
Only at one-way streets
Never, right turns on red are illegal
explanation: Unless prohibited by a sign, you may turn right on red after coming to a complete stop and ensuring it is safe.

question: A sign with a red 'P' and a red slash through it means:
choices: No parking is allowed in this area
Parking is allowed only for a short time
Parking is allowed for permit holders only
No stopping is allowed at any time
explanation: A 'No Parking' sign means you may not park and leave your vehicle unattended, though you may usually stop briefly to load or unload passengers unless other restrictions apply.

question: A sign with a red circle and slash over a hand or the words 'No Stopping' means:
choices: You may not stop your vehicle here, even briefly, except to obey traffic or police
You may stop to load people but not goods
You may park only overnight
Only trucks may stop here
explanation: No stopping zones prohibit stopping for any reason other than obeying traffic controls or police directions.

question: A driver is convicted of improper passing where it is unsafe. How many demerit points does improper passing carry?
choices: 2 demerit points
3 demerit points
4 demerit points
6 demerit points
explanation: Improper passing is a 3-point offence according to Ontario’s demerit points schedule.

question: A police officer gives you directions, but you ignore the signal and are convicted of failing to obey an officer. How many demerit points does this offence carry?
choices: 2 demerit points
3 demerit points
4 demerit points
7 demerit points
explanation: Failing to obey the directions of a police officer carries 3 demerit points in Ontario.

sources.title: Ontario — Demerit points table (failing to obey a police officer)

notes: Distinguishes failing to obey an officer (3 points) from failing to stop for police (7 points).

question: A yellow diamond sign showing a vehicle with wavy skid lines warns drivers to:
choices: Reduce speed because the road may be slippery
Maintain speed because the lanes are straight
Expect loose gravel only in summer
Drive close to the centre line
explanation: This sign warns of slippery conditions, especially on bridges or shaded areas.

question: A broken yellow centre line means:
choices: Passing is allowed when safe
No passing allowed
Lane ends ahead
Traffic merges left
explanation: Broken yellow lines indicate that passing is permitted with caution.

question: A sign showing the pavement higher than the gravel beside it warns of:
choices: A low or soft shoulder
A divided highway
A narrow bridge
A hidden intersection
explanation: A low shoulder can cause loss of control if the vehicle drifts off the pavement.

question: An orange diamond-shaped sign generally indicates:
choices: Road work or construction ahead
School zone
Regulatory speed limit
Hospital zone
explanation: Orange signs warn of temporary construction or maintenance zones.

question: A yellow diamond sign with a deer symbol warns you to:
choices: Be alert for animals crossing, especially at dawn and dusk
Expect a zoo nearby
Stop immediately
Sound your horn continuously
explanation: Wildlife warning signs indicate areas with a higher risk of animal crossings.

question: A rectangular white sign with black numbers such as '80' and the word 'MAXIMUM' means:
choices: The maximum legal speed under ideal conditions is 80 km/h
You must drive exactly 80 km/h
The minimum speed is 80 km/h
You may exceed 80 km/h to pass
explanation: Regulatory speed signs show the maximum legal speed under ideal conditions.

question: A sign showing the end of a school zone speed limit means:
choices: You may resume the regular posted speed when safe
You must continue at school speed at all times
There are no pedestrians beyond this point
School buses no longer stop
explanation: End-of-zone signs indicate where special lower limits no longer apply.

question: A sign showing the right lane ending and an arrow bending into the left lane means:
choices: Right-lane traffic must merge left
Left-lane traffic must stop
Two-way traffic ahead
Passing is allowed on the shoulder
explanation: Merging-lane signs warn drivers to change lanes safely.

question: When you approach a yield sign, you must:
choices: Slow down, be prepared to stop, and yield the right-of-way if another vehicle or pedestrian is in or approaching the intersection
Stop completely every time
Speed up to merge ahead of traffic
Ignore the sign if the road looks clear
explanation: Yield signs require you to give other road users the right-of-way. You must be ready to stop and proceed only when it is safe.

question: At a four-way stop, two vehicles arrive at slightly different times. Who should go first?
choices: The vehicle that came to a complete stop first
The largest vehicle
The vehicle turning left
The vehicle with the loudest horn
explanation: At an all-way stop, the driver who comes to a complete stop first has the right-of-way, if safe to proceed.

question: Under Ontario's escalating sanctions for novice drivers, repeated serious offences can lead to:
choices: Longer suspensions or cancellation of the novice licence
Only a small fine
No penalty beyond demerit points
Unlimited chances with no extra consequences
explanation: Escalating sanctions mean novice drivers face increasing penalties, including longer suspensions or licence cancellation, if they commit multiple serious offences.

question: What blood alcohol concentration (BAC) must G1 drivers maintain while driving?
choices: Zero BAC (no alcohol at all)
Under 0.05 only
Under the legal criminal limit
Any level is allowed with a supervisor
explanation: Novice drivers, including G1, must maintain a BAC of zero while driving in Ontario.

question: When backing a vehicle in a straight line, how should you look to ensure safety?
choices: Turn your body and look through the rear window while backing slowly
Use only your mirrors and backup camera
Look out the driver’s window only
Face forward and glance in the rear-view mirror only
explanation: To reverse safely, turn your body, look through the rear window, and back up slowly, checking all around.

question: If you accidentally entered the paved roadway onto the shoulder, you should:
choices: Ease off the gas, and return to the pavement only when the vehicle is under control and traffic allows
Steer sharply back onto the road immediately
Brake hard and turn quickly
Accelerate to jump back onto the pavement
explanation: A sudden sharp turn back onto the pavement can cause loss of control. Slow gradually and steer back gently when safe.

question: A vehicle is coming toward you in your lane. To reduce the risk of a head-on collision, you should:
choices: Reduce speed, move to the right as far as possible, and be prepared to drive onto the shoulder
Speed up and flash your lights
Move into the oncoming lane to scare the other driver
Close your eyes and brake hard
explanation: Slowing and moving to the right increases space and may help avoid or lessen a collision.

question: If the rear wheels start to skid on a slippery road, you should:
choices: Steer gently in the direction you want the front of the car to go
Brake hard and hold the pedal down
Steer in the opposite direction of the skid
Accelerate to regain traction
explanation: Steering in the direction of the skid helps you regain control by aligning the vehicle with its path.

question: On a freeway with a posted speed of 100 km/h, driving much slower than other traffic without reason is:
choices: Dangerous because it can interfere with traffic flow
Always safest
Required for all G1 drivers
Recommended to save fuel
explanation: Driving much slower than surrounding traffic can be as dangerous as speeding because other drivers may have to brake or change lanes suddenly.

question: On a multi-lane freeway, the left lane is generally used for:
choices: Passing and faster-moving traffic
Parking
Slow-moving vehicles
Learner-driver practice only
explanation: Slower vehicles should keep right, leaving the left lane mostly for passing and faster-moving traffic within the speed limit.

question: A school crossing guard holds up a stop sign at a crosswalk. You must:
choices: Stop and remain stopped until all pedestrians and the guard have cleared your lane
Slow down but continue through carefully
Honk to warn pedestrians to hurry
Stop only if children are present
explanation: Crossing guards have authority to stop traffic. Drivers must obey their signals.

question: At an intersection with a pedestrian crossing but no traffic lights, you should:
choices: Yield to pedestrians who are in or about to enter the crosswalk
Drive through if your light is green
Honk and wave pedestrians across while you move
Ignore pedestrians if you are turning right
explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians at marked or unmarked crosswalks at intersections.

question: You begin to feel very tired while driving at night. What is the safest thing to do?
choices: Find a safe place to stop and rest
Open the window and keep driving
Turn up the radio and drive faster
Follow closely behind another car to stay alert
explanation: Fatigue is dangerous. The safest choice is to stop driving and rest.

question: When should you use your horn?
choices: To alert other road users to a possible danger
To express frustration in traffic
To greet friends you see
To signal that you want the car ahead to speed up
explanation: The horn is a safety device, not for anger or casual use.

question: When is it acceptable to drive with snow or ice covering part of your windshield?
choices: Never; you must fully clear your windshield and windows before driving
As long as you can see directly ahead
Only at low speeds
Only if wipers are working
explanation: Drivers are responsible for having a clear view in all directions before driving.

question: When you see orange construction signs and workers ahead, you should:
choices: Slow down and obey any reduced speed limit
Maintain your usual speed to clear the zone quickly
Honk to warn workers
Use high-beam headlights
explanation: Work zones often have reduced speed limits to protect workers and drivers.

question: Where is the safest place to install a child car seat in most passenger vehicles?
choices: In the rear seat, away from active airbags
In the front seat with the airbag on
In the middle of the front bench seat
Beside the driver’s seat
explanation: The back seat is generally safest, especially away from airbags.

question: A properly worn seatbelt should:
choices: Have the lap belt low over the hips and the shoulder belt across the chest
Cross the stomach and neck
Be placed under the arm for comfort
Be worn loosely so you can move freely
explanation: Correct seatbelt positioning reduces injury risk in a collision.

question: In rain, snow, or poor visibility, how should you adjust your following distance?
choices: Increase it beyond two seconds
Reduce it below two seconds
Keep it exactly the same
Follow closely behind large vehicles
explanation: Poor conditions require greater space to stop safely.

question: When descending a steep, icy hill, you should:
choices: Use a lower gear and brake gently
Shift to neutral and coast
Brake hard continuously
Speed up to reduce time on the hill
explanation: Lower gears and gentle braking improve control on slippery hills.

question: A green light without a green arrow when you are turning left means:
choices: You may turn left when the way is clear and after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians
You have the right-of-way over oncoming traffic
You must wait for a green arrow to turn left
You may not turn left at any time
explanation: A plain green light allows left turns but does not give protected right-of-way.

question: When entering a main road from a driveway or private road, you must:
choices: Yield to all traffic on the main road
Expect traffic on the main road to yield to you
Enter quickly without stopping
Honk and proceed
explanation: Vehicles entering a roadway must yield to traffic already on that road.

question: A G1 driver must be accompanied by a fully licensed driver who:
choices: Has at least four years of driving experience and a BAC of less than 0.05
Is over 16 years old with any licence
Can sit in the back seat
Drives a commercial vehicle
explanation: G1 conditions require a qualified accompanying driver in the front passenger seat.

question: A circular yellow sign with a black 'X' and two 'R's warns of:
choices: An upcoming railway crossing
A hospital zone
A roundabout ahead
An upcoming tunnel
explanation: The railway advance warning sign alerts drivers to an upcoming track crossing.

question: A 'Loading Zone' sign usually means:
choices: Stopping is allowed only for actively loading or unloading
You may park all day
Only buses may park
No stopping is allowed
explanation: Loading zones restrict parking to short stops while goods or passengers are actively loaded or unloaded.

question: When a transit bus signals to leave a stop in a built-up area, you should:
choices: Yield when safe to allow the bus to re-enter traffic
Speed up to pass before it moves
Ignore the signal and maintain speed
Sound your horn until it stays at the stop
explanation: Drivers should show courtesy and allow buses to re-enter traffic when it is safe.

question: When turning left across oncoming traffic, you should begin your turn when:
choices: There is a large enough gap to complete the turn without forcing other drivers to slow down suddenly
You see one car turn behind you
The light is about to turn red
Oncoming vehicles flash their headlights
explanation: Left turns must not interfere with oncoming traffic. Choose a gap that lets you turn smoothly.

question: Running a red light in Ontario can result in:
choices: Fines and demerit points on your driving record
No penalty if no one is hit
